So odious were the fumes of Incense found</br>To that malicious Spirit, who could not bear</br>The smoke, to him heart-piercing; while around</br>The jocund choir their grateful praise declare,</br>Hymning their great Preserver:  nought was there</br>But Love unmingled, and harmonious Song.</br>Then freed from guilt, and resting in the care</br>Of long experienc'd Goodness, the mixt throng</br>To their respective tasks benignant mov'd along.

When to Melampus thus the reverend King:</br>"This general duty paid, where all agreed</br>For general blessings their due lauds to sing;</br>Attend us, Seer, to the descent with speed;</br>Where wait our Eucharistical kids to bleed,</br>For blessings more than health, or life, or food;</br>My Daughters lost restor'd, from folly freed,</br>From error rescued, and to truth renew'd:</br>Peculiar be our Thanks for our peculiar Good!

"The Youths already at the Altar stand,</br>Prepar'd the chosen hecatomb to slay:</br>The shining blade uplifted in their hand,</br>While in loose cords the skipping victims play.</br>On the warm coals the thighs and entrails lay,</br>And pour the blood, Heaven's portion in the feast:</br>These sacred emblems Life and Strength pourtray:</br>And Life and Strength are Heaven's!  This done, the rest</br>Shall furnish the repast.  Be Thou our chiefest guest.

"With joy unbounded will we spread our hearts,</br>Convivials in this Festival divine.</br>While, rank'd in order, all assume their parts,</br>The Banquet's double honours shall be Thine;</br>Unmeasur'd goblets of unmingled wine.</br>The festal Hymns my royal band employ;</br>Let all thy Bards the chearful chorus join.</br>Our raptur'd hearts this day know no alloy;</br>Praise without end to Heaven!  and without measure, Joy!"

"Such pleasures (cried Iphianassa) flow</br>From social virtues, where no guilt upbraids!</br>Such pleasure round the Throne Celestials know,</br>Tune their glad harps, and raise their smiling heads.</br>Triumphing each his golden plumage spreads,</br>When he beholds a mortal wretch forlore</br>Half-dropping to his fate, if back he treads</br>His steps recover'd, wak'd by Wisdom's lore:</br>Their raptures then are great, as were their fears before.

"But oh!  remembrance!  By the same degree</br>These raptures rise, we gage our Father's grief;</br>That grief points out our foul impieties.</br>This sad reflection, like a secret thief,</br>Robs us, Melampus, of thy kind relief.</br>As in the danger, so the joy, our share</br>Might justly claim to be consider'd chief:</br>But we have nought to vow save future care;</br>And all our joys are damp'd with thoughts of what we were."

"No more, Iphianassa!  (said the Seer)</br>Vain were the joy, your safety not complete;</br>Complete your safety, whence the swelling tear?</br>Not to rejoice, were now to doubt your state:</br>And now to doubt it would be most ingrate,</br>And chase the Love so seasonably shown.</br>More insecure is innocence elate,</br>And vaunting in its strength.  The fractur'd bone,</br>At length more firmly knit, acquires a stronger tone."

To him Iphianassa made reply:</br>"From sense of danger scap'd our transport grows:</br>When on that danger I revert my eye,</br>That horrid view distracts me; as the rose</br>Though fair and sweet, upon the prickle blows."</br>"Its guard, as well as parent; (cries the Sage,)</br>And let that thought thy harrass'd mind compose.</br>Resent not thou, when Heaven has dropp'd its rage:</br>Be happy, as he wills; and all thy griefs asswage."

"So deep the sense of what I am, and was,</br>(Returns the Fair) fills my astonish'd thought;</br>Not to be thankful, were a crime more base</br>Than all my past offences.  Mercy brought</br>When wanted most!  unmerited, unsought!</br>What can I offer for such wondrous Love;</br>What but this heart! — Take, Heaven, what thou hast wrought!</br>Here, to my joy indulging, let me rove,</br>Devoted all to Thee, sequester'd in the Grove!"

"Daughter of Praetus, (the good Seer rejoins)</br>Thy wish is incorrect; Heaven never meant</br>Unsocial life:  his boundless goodness shines</br>On countless worlds:  and such his kind intent,</br>Our time, though justly due to Him, is lent</br>To serve our fellow-creatures.  Good enjoy'd</br>Points to do good to others; the cement</br>Uniting all!  then solitude avoid.</br>Wouldst thou be good, do good:  be busied and employ'd."

"Melampus, (thus the Argive Monarch said)</br>While hecatombs and feasts to Heaven we give,</br>No equal recompense to Thee is paid;</br>Such as a King may offer, Thou receive.</br>Canst thou be drawn th' Arcadian Grove to leave?</br>My lov'd Iphianassa shall be thine,</br>And Argos shall Arcadia's loss retrieve.</br>A third of all my empire I resign,</br>And thou to priestly cares shalt royal counsels join."

"Rich in herself I take the great reward</br>(Melampus cries) her ample dowry's light</br>With her inestimable worth compar'd.</br>With this good hand unchanging Faith I plight,</br>Raiment and Food, and each Connubial right.</br>Has ought Iphianassa to object?</br>Not force, but mutual wills, can hearts unite:</br>There languid nature cools not to neglect;</br>But age, that ripens merit, heightens the respect."

"It ill becomes a daughter to dispute</br>Her Father's pleasure, (said the Royal Fair.)</br>Obedience and compliance better suit</br>Her weakness, shelter'd by paternal care:</br>But, oh my Royal Father, here forbear</br>To urge your power.  I know the debt immense</br>I owe to good Melampus; shall I dare</br>His virtues with my crimes to recompense?</br>In penance let me live, and weep my foul offence."

"Her crimes (returns Melampus) who shall blame</br>Who from the lustral wave renew'd ascends?</br>Not that I'd lessen or their guilt, or shame.</br>So much on female chastity depends,</br>With justice infamy its breach attends.</br>But where we see a charge sincere obtain,</br>There strengthen'd virtue every pass defends:</br>While those of one poor virtue blindly vain,</br>See not a thousand faults, and wear a careless rein."

The Damsel then:  "My Father, must I lose</br>Your sheltering care, your mild and honour'd sway?</br>With this hand goes my heart:  if you refuse,</br>And give it from you, with it you convey</br>The chief affections of my heart away.—</br>'Tis Praetus' gift, Melampus, though but small;</br>At once the pledge and proof that I obey.</br>If Heaven and You receive me from my fall,</br>Share both this thankful heart, till Heaven shall claim it All."

"A moment we the Sacrifice postpone</br>(The Monarch cried) till we consult the Grove,</br>Yon close recess, the God's immediate Throne.</br>Where, as the Laurel's leafy tongues shall move,</br>We read if Heaven our last resolve approve.</br>Melampus, call the interpreters around,</br>From Pelias sprung, the Dodonian Dove,</br>To watch each nodding branch and mystick sound,</br>And from the rustling boughs your future fates expound.

"If Heaven auspicious to our wish assent,</br>This day shall be a day of joy indeed.</br>Soon shall th' Espousals gain the purpose meant,</br>And Marriage Rites to Marriage Vows succeed.</br>Cleans'd from their gall new hecatombs shall bleed,</br>To lengthen out the Eucharistical feast.</br>The Nuptial Crown do thou, Ipponoe, braid</br>With Myrtle and Amaracus embrac'd:</br>Lysippe, mix the flour, and knead the bridal paste.

"With lighted torch the boys the Bride shall bring,</br>To Thetis' lap when Phoebus is declin'd;</br>While round the Bards the Hymeneals sing,</br>By fife and lute in grateful concert join'd:</br>The active youth the circling dance shall wind;</br>Now act the fight, now imitate the chase,</br>Stoop, bound, and fly, and turn; the Maids behind</br>With twinkling feet shall step the measur'd pace;</br>And shew how sweet the accord of Fortitude and Grace."

"Elfenor, (said Melampus) thou shalt be</br>The Bridegroom's Friend, the wedding-ring to bear,</br>Neat, without ornament:  firm constancy</br>The Iron shall engage; its form declare</br>Truth that shall know no end.  Thou too prepare</br>The Myrtle wreaths to deck the Bridegroom's bowers.</br>My Mother dead, take Thou a Mother's care</br>To weave my Garland mixt with various flowers:</br>And witness for us both, if Love sincere be ours."

To him Elfenor:  "The vast debt I owe,</br>O more than Father!  cannot be express'd,</br>For this chang'd heart, where peace and pleasure grow,</br>Joy without tumult, without langour rest.</br>Mercy triumphant reigns, and in my breast</br>An infant Conscience smiles:  no guilt to annoy,</br>No craving selfish passions to molest;</br>No envious grudges my own peace destroy,</br>And every happy object round me, gives me joy.

"What happy prospects open to my view</br>From this day's Nuptials, if I right forecast!</br>Not more sincere delight my Mother knew</br>When first she saw thee, and embrac'd thee fast,</br>And thank'd the Gods for all her travail past.</br>In thee, Melampus, we with joy discern</br>That Virtue meets a full reward at last:</br>In Thee, fair Nymph, more joyful truth we learn;</br>Heaven's arms are open'd wide to Sinners who return.

"HE seeks the wandering sheep, the wounded hart,</br>Knows with his crook to drive, or pipe to allure,</br>To heal the sick, or draw the bearded dart:</br>SHE hears the Shepherd's voice, near fountains pure,</br>Nor shuns the cleansing stream, nor slights her cure.</br>Your Names shall mark some young recording tree:</br>Like Them your Loves increase, like Them endure;</br>And give the world a generous progeny,</br>Like fair Iphianassa good, and wise like Thee."

At the East end, upon a gentle rise,</br>Thick intertangled Laurels form'd a screen;</br>The Secret Place conceal'd from public eyes,</br>By none but Kings and chosen Prophets seen,</br>And those Interpreters who dwelt within,</br>To read the mystick signs, and thence translate</br>The Visions, Motions, Sounds, or sacred Sheen,</br>In arduous matters, or nice points of state;</br>Their Counsels to direct, or open future fate.

"While I and Praetus are admitted there,</br>You wait the answer here," (Melampus cried.)</br>To pass the leafy veil they now prepare:</br>When strait a sudden lustre from the skies</br>Shot through the gloom; the wind began to rise,</br>And, gliding through the trees on easy wings,</br>A Form celestial skims before their eyes:</br>In the strong gale his fluttering mantle sings,</br>And wheeling round the court he forms his lessening rings.

Then drops, and to Elfenor wav'd his hand:</br>Wings fledg'd his feet, and wings embrac'd his head;</br>His fingers lightly held a feather'd wand.</br>Then to Elfenor thus the Herald said:</br>"Beloved of Heaven, all hail!  from thence I'm sped</br>The Messenger of wrath; thy doom was fix'd,</br>The irrevocable sentence spake thee dead.</br>How interesting the interval betwixt!</br>Despair griev'd all our hosts, and not a hope was mixt.

"Despair without a hope fill'd all our host,</br>All but Celestial LOVE'S Eternal Son.</br>He knew that I but little speed could boast:</br>Wing'd though I was to see the sentence done,</br>Indulgent LOVE vouchsaf'd me only one.</br>He shot before me like a trailing star,</br>Whose course seems finish'd soon as 'tis begun.</br>Intent to save thee, on his winged car</br>He rush'd impetuous down:  I mark'd him from afar.

"This Grove he sought, and Zephyr sent to thee</br>To lead thee hither.  What employ'd the eve,</br>And what the night, thou need'st not learn from me;</br>What arts he us'd thy losses to retrieve,</br>And baffle Anteros labouring to deceive,</br>Making Melampus his free instrument:</br>But hard the task, and arduous to atchieve,</br>To bring a heart so harden'd to relent,</br>And vengeance, on a sinner doom'd to die, prevent.

"This morning, when the disappointed foe,</br>Scar'd at the fumes of Incense, fled away;</br>Despairing of success by wiles below,</br>He boldly ventur'd to the realms of day,</br>And claim'd Thee as his due and forfeit prey.</br>LOVE hung on high his equal scales in air;</br>Thy Duty that, this thy Discharge to weigh;</br>Thy merits here, and they Transgressions there:</br>Our Hosts were griev'd, the Fiend shouted at the Compare.

"When upward sprang LOVE'S Son with rapid sail,</br>Endeavouring to weigh up the cumbrous lett.</br>He threw with care into the opposing scale</br>(As balance to the long neglected debt;)</br>Thy copious tears, and deep unfeign'd regret:</br>(Against thy crimes;) thy conquest in the Grove,</br>Thy filial Trust, new resolutions set;</br>And last, which made the trembling balance move,</br>Thy Prayers, thy raptur'd Praise, and Universal Love.

"The Fiend objected both to weight and kind;</br>Tears were not virtue, but its want proclaim'd:</br>Not e'en though future reformation join'd;</br>For partial virtue was but virtue maim'd:</br>Nay e'en that partial virtue he defam'd</br>By calumnies and lies:  these in he threw</br>Pressing the adverse beam.  Thy Patron claim'd</br>Thy full discharge on fixt conditions due.</br>This sunk thy weightier scale, and up the Traytor's flew.

"Thy full discharge obtain'd, to me he sped,</br>And bade me haste my errand:  then he stuck</br>Wings on my feet, and feathers to my head:</br>From my right hand, with vengeance arm'd, he took</br>My Harpe, dreadful with its swinging crook:</br>And as he gave benign his mild command,</br>From my sharp dart the bearded point he strook;</br>Which fell upon Eumolpus; in my hand</br>A pointless shaft he left, this wing'd, but powerful wand.

"Haste to Elfenor, said the FILIAL LOVE;</br>His trial past, his exercises done,</br>His prize adjudg'd, how cruel wouldst thou prove,</br>Shouldst thou delay his amaranthine Crown,</br>And keep him from the palm so hardly won!</br>Thy rod shall gently steal his life away,</br>(For Death's wide gate can be escap'd by none.)</br>Then (cast his pristine form) in bright array</br>Thy rod shall call him forth to an eternal day.

"Should doubts arise, if such a change can be,</br>And inexperience tempt thee to diffide;</br>Thyself the wonders of this rod shalt see,</br>An earnest of the change that shall betide."</br>A snake then chanc'd athwart the green to glide,</br>In playful volumes innocently roll'd:</br>The Herald to his crested head applied</br>The magic wand; which, wondrous to behold!</br>Induc'd a sudden age, and dimm'd his scales of gold.

He languishes and dies;  the muscles tough</br>(Wound round his rod) like wire in spirals hung:</br>Strait from the colourless and lifeless slough</br>The snake renew'd, in golden verdure young,</br>Shot forth, and to the rod entwisted clung.</br>Elfenor view'd with pleasure and surprise</br>How quick with life the active muscles sprung;</br>What brighter hues the magick touch supplies,</br>What lustre paints his form, what lightnings in his eyes.

"This may assure thy faith (the Herald said:)</br>Thine eyes this sleep-inducing Wand must seal;</br>Thy form grown rigid, and thy colours shed,</br>A soft deliquium on thy sense shall steal,</br>And no disease or agony shall feel.</br>Then soon this life-inspiring wand will smite</br>Death's iron grasp, shake off this cumbrous veil;</br>And lead thee forth array'd in glory bright</br>Up to yon realms of day among the suns of light."

"Gracious thy message, kind thy care has been,</br>Celestial Herald! (pleas'd Elfenor cried;)</br>For weak's the evidence of things not seen,</br>And our frail frame shrinks at a change untried:</br>But Truth and Goodness bid me to confide.</br>These every doubt and every fear restrain;</br>The heart that feels them needs no proof beside:</br>Nay, Nature's self a change will ascertain;</br>Where all things die to rise in other states again.

"We see the day decline, and die in night,</br>Then rises waken'd to a beauteous morn:</br>Dead winter springs, and darkness puts on light.</br>From what small seeds, or little grain of corn,</br>The stately stalk, or spreading tree, are born!</br>Dropp'd in the mould and perish'd, they spring forth</br>In other forms, which flowers and fruits adorn.</br>Why may not worms, as we are, leave in earth</br>An empty film to rot, and know a nobler birth?

"Wheree'er Heaven calls, or wheresoe'er he leads,</br>I follow ready, to his will resign'd:</br>Whatever world or scene of things succeeds,</br>He reigns through all, and I can nothing find</br>That I should dread, while he continues kind."</br>This said, the Herald gave the gentle stroke;</br>Elfenor faints; upon the bank reclin'd</br>Melampus stretch'd him:  when in part he woke,</br>And lift his dying eyes, and thus prophetick spoke:

"Darkness creeps o'er the present and the past,</br>While Time draws back the veil from all before.</br>The opening prospect lengthens wild and vast,</br>A Sea immense, whose boisterous billows roar</br>The sport of winds, and hide the distant shore.</br>The crouded scene, Melampus, moves from Thee</br>And thy illustrious Bride; an age, or more,</br>On Argos throne thy Royal race I see,</br>Fill'd with the inspiring God, and heavenly Augury.

"Ah!  what avails, Amphiaraus, thy skill,</br>To know the end, unweeting of the mean?</br>Thou fall'st at Thebes:  in vain th' impending ill</br>In fate's reflected mirror was foreseen.</br>Thou fall'st thy people's Saviour; while thy Queen</br>Smiles on her bracelet!  nor conclude it hard:</br>For Heaven in mercy shuts thy mortal scene</br>In flower of life and virtue, for reward:</br>The guilty shall awhile for ripening wrath be spar'd.

"Thy sons thy death revenge; who exil'd mourn</br>The vengeance unbecoming pious hands,</br>From their own country, and from empire torn:</br>Too faithful to a Father's last commands!</br>I see thy offspring cast on other lands;</br>O'er the wide North to Western seas they rove,</br>And as they spread, Religion's light expands:</br>Priests, Prophets, Bards, to instruct the nations move,</br>And plant in distant climes their Hyperesian Grove.

"Meanwhile, Lust, Rapine, and Revenge through Greece</br>Shake every state, and trouble every shore:</br>War flings her iron lance, and frightens Peace.</br>Here the Cadmean Lyon's heard to roar;</br>There whets his tusk the Caledonian Boar;</br>Now Lydia flees before the Median Mule;</br>There Persia's Ram shall dip his horn in gore:</br>Graecia's rough Goat shall break the Persian rule;</br>The Goat an Eagle tear, and stretch her wings to Thule.

"Religion takes it's colour from the age,</br>A minister to Lust, or stern debate;</br>Warriors grow Gods, those Gods in factions rage,</br>While oracles are made the tools of state.</br>Pale Superstition, busy to create</br>Phantoms for fear, those phantoms to appease</br>With bloody victims bribe infernal Hate:</br>Idolatry, intent on what it sees,</br>Turns Symbols into Gods, and deifies her Trees.

"Thy Druids, in their Western clime secure,</br>Tread not the walks of War, or Error's maze:</br>Chief on yon spot, which whitening seas immure,</br>Whose stones are tin, shall Truth's enlight'ning rays</br>Distinguish'd shine, and gild her lengthen'd days.</br>Safe from incursions and from hostile camps,</br>Their manners know no mixtures or decays:</br>While realms around, as time their lustre damps,</br>Here light their torch at Truth, and trim their faded lamps.

"Untainted with the vices of the times,</br>Here Virtue long her peaceful reign shall hold;</br>Fenc'd less by Laws than ignorance of crimes.</br>Some the choice Medicines of the fields unfold;</br>Some deal out Justice undeceiv'd by gold:</br>When danger threats, or languid nature pants,</br>They smile at death, in future prospects bold:</br>Their God no Walls confine, no Image scants,</br>But in their Groves devout they trace him through the plants.

"But spite of care, or fierce surrounding seas,</br>Elfin corruption shews at length its stain;</br>Till conscious guilt, the wrath she dreads, to appease,</br>Shall float with blood of Elfin victims slain</br>The horrid Altars, and the Grove prophane.</br>Their crimes the Eagle from afar shall call,</br>Scenting its prey, to hover o'er their plain:</br>Then shall thy Druids bleed, their Oaks shall fall,</br>Error, and Vice, and War, and Vengeance harrass All.

"What total darkness overspreads the Earth,</br>In every clime extinguish'd every ray!</br>O wake!  and give the promis'd Blessing birth,</br>And light the nations with returning day!</br>I see a sceptre rise which wide shall sway:</br>See yonder star a stream of glory pour!</br>Bow down, ye Potentates!  with joy obey</br>The expected King!  the Star foretold of yore,</br>Ye Wise, with rapture know, and wonder, and adore!

"The Branch Divine!  the Rod of heavenly root!</br>The Sovereign Balm, whose fragrance fills the skies.</br>From sea to sea the encreasing Plant shall shoot.</br>Intent on Him, ye Nations, fix your eyes,</br>Who food and medicine to your tribes supplies:</br>Heals Superstition with celestial Love;</br>Nor longer bids the bloody Altars rise:</br>Idols and Symbol worship to remove,</br>Plants in the heart renew'd his Intellectual Grove.

"Anteros, his threaten'd empire to maintain,</br>Rouses the powers of Earth and all their arts</br>To oppose Religion, and prevents it's reign.</br>Vice trembles through her states; Imposture starts,</br>And lurking Malice shoots her poyson'd darts.</br>Fierce Interest and blind Prejudice unite;</br>Kings and Philosophers espouse their parts.</br>Through fiery storms, and all the rage of spight,</br>She moves victorious on, and trails her robe of white.

"Soon to her staff shall regal sceptres bow,</br>And Kings in dowry their domains bestow.</br>Then Anteros shall put on a solemn brow</br>In sanctity assum'd.  Hence springs new woe!</br>Hence Pride, Ambition, fierce Contention flow;</br>Scholastick webs, the raging lust of power,</br>Imperious Zeal, vain Pomp, and Tinsel Show.</br>Foes, guis'd like friends, suppress Religion's lore,</br>Dawb her fair face with paint, and stain her robe with gore.

"Once more thy sons, what of thy sons remain,</br>In yonder spot the Cassiterian Isle,</br>Shall blotted Truth and Purity again</br>In youthful grace and beauty make to smile.</br>To Them she flies from Rome's tyrannick soil,</br>And from her feet shakes off the attesting dust:</br>Thy Kings protect her from assault and guile.</br>Learning wipes off Tradition's sordid rust,</br>And Freedom's hands the chains of forc'd compulsion burst.

"But lo!  the prospect deepens!  sails unfurl'd</br>Whiten the seas, and journey with the sun!</br>No longer Thule bounds the Western World;</br>New shores are open'd, and new realms are won.</br>From port to port see restless Commerce run,</br>And high in air her rigid balance hold!</br>By thirst of gain Religion now's undone;</br>In open market every virtue sold,</br>And God himself exchang'd for late-discover'd Gold.

"This shrinking mischief, with confusion big,</br>Swallows whole empires in her ravenous maw,</br>While mutual graves their mutual falchions dig.</br>Intent on this the rival nations draw</br>With endless rage War's ever-changing saw.</br>Deceit, and Fraud, and Luxury, and Pride,</br>Corruption's teint, and wrong-defending Law,</br>With every artifice of vice beside,</br>Debauch a selfish world, and spread Disorder wide.

"O blind to every Good!  to Evil prone!</br>O thoughtless, creeping reptiles of a day!</br>Heaven wakes to vengeance.  Hark, the nations groan!</br>Kings and their armies flee to dread dismay.</br>The thunders roar, the forky lightnings play;</br>In horrid shower the burning sulphurs fall,</br>The Oceans hiss, the mountains melt away;</br>Fierce fires and flames enwrap the blazing ball,</br>And Desolation draws her dreadful sweep o'er all.

"Happy, thrice happy those distinguish'd Few,</br>Who, listening early to Religion's lore,</br>From earthly objects their affections drew!</br>Their eyes and wishes fixt on yonder shore,</br>Where want, and pain, and death shall be no more.</br>Incessant glories beam upon my sight!</br>On new-sprung wings my Spirit pants to soar,</br>And reach the regions of celestial light.</br>Adieu!  Earth's bubble breaks, and sinks in endless night."

Thus spake the Prophet, and then clos'd his eyes,</br>Stretch'd at his length, and number'd with the dead.</br>Again his wand the Herald then applies,</br>And from his clay-cold stiff'ning carcase fled</br>The inward form, on stranger-pinions sped.</br>Once a vile worm, and reptile son of clay,</br>He mounts on wings of radiant colours spread,</br>Chang'd in his powers, and clad in bright array,</br>Dear to the Son of LOVE, amidst the realms of Day.</br>
